{{Infobox military person |name=Niketas Oöryphas |image= |caption= |birth_date= |death_date= |birth_place= |death_place= |nickname= |allegiance=[[Byzantine Empire]] |rank=''[[droungarios#Byzantine navy|droungarios tou ploïmou]]'' |battles=[[Byzantine–Arab Wars]] |relations= |laterwork= }} '''Niketas Oryphas''' or '''Oöryphas''' ({{lang-el|{{lang|grc|Νικήτας ὁ Ὀρύφας}}}} or {{lang|grc|Ὠορυφᾶς}}, fl. 860–873)<ref name=Winkelmann441>{{harvnb|Winkelmann|Lilie|Ludwig|Pratsch|2000|p=441}}.</ref> was a distinguished [[Byzantine Empire|Byzantine]] official, [[patrikios|patrician]],<ref name=CP130>{{harvnb|Constantine Porphyrogenitus|Bekkerus|1840|loc="De Administrando Imperio", p. 130}}.</ref> and admiral under the [[Byzantine emperors]] [[Michael III]] (r. 842–867) and [[Basil I the Macedonian]] (r. 867–886), who achieved several naval victories against the [[Emirate of Crete|Cretan Saracen]] raiders.
==Biography==
===Under Michael III=== [[File:Saracen fleet against Crete.jpg|thumb|250px|right|Saracen corsairs, from the ''[[Madrid Skylitzes]]'' manuscript.]]
Nothing is known of Niketas Ooryphas's early life. Several people surnamed Ooryphas are recorded in sources during the first half of the 9th century, all of them in high naval positions, but any family relation is conjectural.<ref>{{harvnb|Winkelmann|Lilie|Ludwig|Pratsch|2000|pp=442, 487–488}}.</ref>
Niketas Ooryphas first appears in our sources in 860, as [[urban prefect]] of [[Constantinople]], when a [[Rus' (people)|Rus']] fleet [[Rus'–Byzantine War (860)|suddenly appeared]] in the entrance to the [[Bosporus]] and started pillaging the city's suburbs. In his capacity as urban prefect, Ooryphas made a report to Emperor Michael III, who was campaigning against the [[Arabs]] in [[Asia Minor]]. At a subsequent date, he was appointed in a position in the [[Byzantine navy]], and in 867 he was in charge of the Imperial Fleet (''[[droungarios tou ploïmou]]'').<ref name=Winkelmann441/> As such he sailed with 100 ships in relief of [[Dubrovnik|Ragusa]] against an [[Siege of Ragusa (866–868)|Arab siege]] which had already lasted 15 months,<ref name=CP130/> and restored the imperial suzerainty over the coasts of [[Dalmatia]].<ref>{{harvnb|Runciman|1988|p=215}}.</ref> It is, however, possible that Ooryphas already had naval experience, as he may be identifiable with one of the commanders of the [[Sack of Damietta (853)|853 attack]] on [[Damietta]].<ref>{{harvnb|Winkelmann|Lilie|Ludwig|Pratsch|2000|p=488}}.</ref>
===Under Basil the Macedonian=== [[File:Romans (Niketas Oryphas) punish Cretan Saracens.jpg|thumb|250px|Ooryphas punishes the Cretan Saracens, as depicted in the ''Madrid Skylitzes''.]]
Although he had risen to high rank under Michael III and had protested the usurpation of the Byzantine throne by Basil I the Macedonian in 867, Ooryphas was quickly won over and retained in office by the latter,<ref name=Winkelmann441/> and went on to become the perhaps most successful Byzantine admiral of his age.<ref>{{harvnb|Jenkins|1987|p=192}}.</ref>
In 869, Ooryphas led the Byzantine fleet that sailed in support of [[Louis II of Italy|Louis II]] who was besieging [[Bari]], but on arriving there, he found the [[Franks|Frankish]] army dispersed in winter quarters, and caused a diplomatic episode by referring to Louis, who claimed the title of ''Emperor of the Romans'', merely as "king". As a result of the quarrel, the main part of the Byzantine force left, without participating in the siege of the city.<ref>{{harvnb|Jenkins|1987|p=187}}.</ref>
In ca. 873, Ooryphas [[Battle of Kardia|defeated]] the [[Cretan Saracens]] in the [[Gulf of Saros]],<ref>{{harvnb|Pryor|Jeffreys|2006|p=61}}.</ref> and soon after followed this success with another: while the Saracens were campaigning off the western coasts of [[Greece]], he had his men drag his ships overland across the [[Isthmus of Corinth]], thereby surprising the Saracen fleet in the [[Corinthian Gulf]] and defeating them.<ref>{{harvnb|Treadgold|1997|p=457}}.</ref> Ooryphas subsequently disappears from the scene, although he may have led the Imperial Fleet in its actions for a few years before being replaced by the ''droungarios'' [[Nasar]], including the recapture of Bari and, briefly, of [[Cyprus]].<ref>{{harvnb|Treadgold|1997|p=458}}.</ref>
